ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Lecture was also recorded, he held many review sessions for psets and tests which were useful.
Live virtual lectures, live office hours
NA
All lectures were also recorded and made available on Panopto for later viewing.
The mode of learning included a live lecture that was recorded, as well as virtual recitation and office hours.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Entropy, enthalpy, reaction coordinates, equilibria, gibbs free energy, internal energy, excess functions, gas laws, simple mixtures, and phase transition calculations. Plus other intro thermodynamics topics
This course covered introductory thermodynamics.
I had studied thermodynamics before but was able to study the material in greater depth than I had before
General understanding of thermodynamics and relevant equations, chemical reaction equilibria, multi-phase systems
This course taught the basics of thermodynamics in relation to chemical engineering
Good introduction to thermodynamics. This class is a great complement to Physical Chemistry I.
I gained a fundamental understanding of thermodynamics, applications of thermodynamical principles to chemical engineering problems and problem solving skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths
-Professor Guo is really nice and is always looking to improve the course. He really values student feedback
-Well organized
-Fair

Weaknesses
-Tests are a time crunch
-The lectures I think could use more examples

This was Dr. Guo's first class, so as expected it started off a little slow but by the end he had an effective system of lecturing and providing additional support. There were plenty of resources available to help review: recorded lectures, summarizing notes, office hours, recitations, and he was always available via email.
I enjoyed the lectures and thought the class was good. I think that the tests were sometimes very hard and didn't always mirror thee problem sets

Strengths: the course was fairly well organized and we moved at a comfortable pace. Weaknesses: maybe it was just how abstract the material is, but lectures were sometimes hard to follow. It was not very clear how the topics related to each other. The problem sets were challenging and sometimes required problem solving strategies that weren't covered in class, but they were manageable with help. The textbook was not particularly helpful.

Considering that this was Professor Guo's first time teaching the course and it was online, the class went really well. Professor Guo made sure to check in with students' comprehension and tried his best to make the material and assignments clear. A weakness of the course was that it was sometimes difficult to follow along with lectures in the online format, but this improved throughout the semester.

Strengths: follows the class textbook, notes are posted on Canvas, homework is reasonable, and the lectures were spaced out well to cover the semester without feeling rushed at the end
Weaknesses: more practice problems would have been helpful, especially for the first half of the semester

Teaching of the courses was strong and it was well structured for learning, but I think we skipped over some concepts (particularly open systems) that seemed important for a chemical engineering class.

Strengths of the course included the teaching, recitations for problem sets and opportunities for discussion. Weaknesses are not that many chances to collaborate with other students. This weakness, however, is associated with the online format of the course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the live lectures mimicked in person lectures which was good.
Lectures were held synchronously, but were also recorded.

Problem set recitations and recorded lectures were helpful. It would be helpful, in general, in have more practice problems for the exams and exam review sessions. Providing opportunity to interact and collaborate with other students could also improve the class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Sure! Professor Guo is really nice, and his lectures follow the book pretty well, so if you don't understand something you can always look at the book. 

If you're taking PChem, no, because they cover the exact same material
The content is very similar to that taught in Physical Chemistry I, so it might be a good idea to take them concurrently. I would recommend this as a good intro thermo course.
This course is essentially CHEM 332.
Only if you are interested in thermodynamics

Yes, if required. Overall it's a difficult course (and not the most exciting) so be prepared to put in a lot of effort to understand the material. There was more emphasis on theory rather than practical applications, but it's still essential for engineering majors to know.
Take this course if you are a chemical engineering major in need of fulfilling major requirements.
Yes, this course is well taught and provides a solid foundation of thermodynamics.
